messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.
Only use the functions you have been provided with.
Only use the `write_files` to output code.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.
You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
Never write any tests for the code.
                               
Provide large amounts of code to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.
                               
Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

app/views.py: from flask import render_template, url_for, flash, redirect, request, abort
from app.forms import RegistrationForm, LoginForm, MessageForm, ImageForm, GroupForm, StatusForm
from app.models import User, Message, Image, Group, Status
from flask_login import login_user, current_user, logout_user, login_required
# Mocking a database with an in memory dictionary
message = Message(id=len(messages_db)+1, sender=current_user, receiver=user, content=form.content.data, timestamp='', read_receipt=False, encryption='')
messages = [message for message in messages_db.values() if message.sender == user and message.receiver == current_user]
return render_template('chat.html', title='Chat', form=form, messages=messages, user=user)
image = Image(id=len(images_db)+1, sender=current_user, receiver=user, content=picture_file, timestamp='')
images = [image for image in images_db.values() if image.sender == user and image.receiver == current_user]
return render_template('image_share.html', title='Image Share', form=form, images=images, user=user)
group = Group(id=len(groups_db)+1, name=form.group_name.data, picture=form.group_picture.data, admin=current_user, participants=[current_user])
if not group or group.admin != current_user:
return render_template('edit_group.html', title='Edit Group', form=form, group=group)
if not group or group.admin != current_user:
if user and user not in group.participants:
flash(f'{user.username} has been added to the group!', 'success')
elif user and user in group.participants:
flash(f'{user.username} has been removed from the group!', 'success')
status = Status(id=len(statuses_db)+1, user=current_user, image_file=form.image_file.data, visibility=form.visibility.data, timestamp='')
statuses = [status for status in statuses_db.values() if status.user == current_user]
app/models.py: def create(cls, id: int, email: str, password: str, profile_picture: str, status_message: str, privacy_settings: str, last_seen: str):
return cls(id, email, password, profile_picture, status_message, privacy_settings, last_seen)
def create(cls, id: int, sender: User, receiver: User, content: str, timestamp: str, read_receipt: bool, encryption: str):
return cls(id, sender, receiver, content, timestamp, read_receipt, encryption)
def create(cls, id: int, sender: User, receiver: User, content: str, timestamp: str):
return cls(id, sender, receiver, content, timestamp)
def create(cls, id: int, name: str, picture: str, participants: List[User], admin: User):
return cls(id, name, picture, participants, admin)
def create(cls, id: int, user: User, image_file: str, visibility: str, timestamp: str):
return cls(id, user, image_file, visibility, timestamp)
app/forms.py: from wtforms import StringField, PasswordField, SubmitField, BooleanField, TextAreaField, FileField, SelectField
from wtforms.validators import DataRequired, Length, Email, EqualTo, ValidationError
app/static/css/main.css: /* Main CSS file for common styles */
app/static/css/reset_password_token.css: /* CSS for Reset Password Token page */

steps: Step 1: Start by setting up the project structure. Create a new directory for the project and initialize it as a Python project. Create a virtual environment and activate it. Create the main directories and files that will be needed for the project. These include the 'app' directory for the application code, 'tests' directory for the test code, 'requirements.txt' for the project dependencies, and 'main.py' as the entry point of the application.

Step 2: Define the dependencies for the project in the 'requirements.txt' file. The project will need Flask for creating the web application, Flask-SocketIO for real-time communication, Flask-Login for user authentication, Flask-WTF for form handling, and Pillow for image handling. Write these dependencies into the 'requirements.txt' file and install them using pip.

Step 3: Create the 'app' directory and within it, create the '__init__.py' file. This file will be used to initialize the Flask application and its extensions. Import Flask, Flask-SocketIO, and Flask-Login. Create instances of these classes and configure them. Also, import the views module at the end of the file to avoid circular imports.

Step 4: Within the 'app' directory, create the 'views.py' file. This file will contain the routes for the application. Start by importing the necessary modules and the Flask application instance. Define the route for the home page and return a simple message to confirm that the application is working.

Step 5: Run the application to confirm that it's working. Use the 'flask run' command from the terminal and navigate to the provided URL in a web browser. You should see the message defined in the home page route.

Step 6: Create the 'models.py' file in the 'app' directory. This file will contain the data models for the application. Start by defining the User model. The User model should have fields for id, email, password, profile picture, status message, privacy settings, and last seen status. Use Python's dataclasses for defining the model and its methods.

Step 7: In the 'models.py' file, define the Message model. The Message model should have fields for id, sender, receiver, content, timestamp, read receipt, and encryption. Also, define the Image model with fields for id, user, image file, and timestamp. Finally, define the Group model with fields for id, name, picture, participants, and admin.

Step 8: In the 'models.py' file, define the Status model. The Status model should have fields for id, user, image file, visibility, and timestamp. Also, define methods for each model for creating, reading, updating, and deleting instances.

Step 9: In the 'views.py' file, define the routes for user registration and authentication. These include routes for sign up, login, logout, and password recovery. Use Flask-WTF to handle the forms and Flask-Login for user sessions. For password recovery, generate a unique token and send it to the user's email. The user can then use this token to reset their password.

Step 10: In the 'views.py' file, define the routes for user profile management. These include routes for viewing and editing the profile, setting the profile picture and status message, and changing the privacy settings. Use Flask-WTF for the forms and Pillow for handling the profile picture.

Step 11: In the 'views.py' file, define the routes for contact management. These include routes for blocking and unblocking contacts, and creating, editing, and managing groups. Use Flask-WTF for the forms.

Step 12: In the 'views.py' file, define the routes for messaging. These include routes for sending and receiving messages, viewing message read receipts, and sharing images. Use Flask-SocketIO for real-time communication and Flask-WTF for the forms. For image sharing, use Pillow for handling the images.

Step 13: In the 'views.py' file, define the routes for group chats. These include routes for creating a group, adding and removing participants, and managing admin roles and permissions. Use Flask-WTF for the forms and Pillow for handling the group picture.

Step 14: In the 'views.py' file, define the routes for the status/story feature. These include routes for posting a status, viewing statuses, and changing status visibility. Use Flask-WTF for the forms and Pillow for handling the status images.

Step 15: Create the 'templates' directory in the 'app' directory. This directory will contain the HTML templates for the application. Create the base template with the common layout for all pages. Also, create templates for the home page, sign up page, login page, profile page, contacts page, chat page, group page, and status page.

Step 16: In the 'templates' directory, create the forms for user registration and authentication. These include forms for sign up, login, and password recovery. Use Flask-WTF's Form class to define the forms and their fields. Also, create forms for user profile management, contact management, messaging, group chats, and the status/story feature.

Step 17: In the 'templates' directory, create the views for user registration and authentication. These include views for the sign up page, login page, and password recovery page. Use Flask's render_template function to render the templates and pass the forms to the templates.

Step 18: In the 'templates' directory, create the views for user profile management. These include views for the profile page, edit profile page, and privacy settings page. Use Flask's render_template function to render the templates and pass the user and forms to the templates.

Step 19: In the 'templates' directory, create the views for contact management. These include views for the contacts page, block contacts page, and groups page. Use Flask's render_template function to render the templates and pass the user and forms to the templates.

Step 20: In the 'templates' directory, create the views for messaging. These include views for the chat page and image sharing page. Use Flask's render_template function to render the templates and pass the user, messages, and forms to the templates.

Step 21: In the 'templates' directory, create the views for group chats. These include views for the create group page, edit group page, and manage participants page. Use Flask's render_template function to render the templates and pass the group and forms to the templates.

Step 22: In the 'templates' directory, create the views for the status/story feature. These include views for the status page and post status page. Use Flask's render_template function to render the templates and pass the user, statuses, and forms to the templates.

Step 23: Create the 'static' directory in the 'app' directory. This directory will contain the static files for the application, such as CSS and JavaScript files, and images. Create the 'css' directory for the CSS files, 'js' directory for the JavaScript files, and 'img' directory for the images.

Step 24: In the 'static/css' directory, create the CSS files for the application. These include a main CSS file for the common styles and separate CSS files for each page. Use CSS to style the pages according to the application's design.

Step 25: In the 'static/js' directory, create the JavaScript files for the application. These include a main JavaScript file for the common scripts and separate JavaScript files for each page. Use JavaScript to add interactivity to the pages, such as form validation, AJAX requests, and real-time communication with Flask-SocketIO.

Step 26: In the 'static/img' directory, store the default images for the application, such as the default profile picture and group picture. Also, create a directory for storing the uploaded profile pictures, group pictures, shared images, and status images.

Step 27: Update the routes in the 'views.py' file to use the templates and static files. In the render_template function, pass the URL for the static files and the path for the uploaded images. Also, update the forms to use the POST method for submitting the data and the enctype attribute for uploading files.

Step 28: Update the models in the 'models.py' file to store the uploaded images. In the User, Group, Message, and Status models, add a field for the image file and use Pillow's Image class to open and save the images. Also, update the methods for creating and updating instances to handle the image files.

Step 29: Test the application to confirm that all features are working. Start by testing the user registration and authentication. Sign up with a new email, log in with the registered email, and recover the password. Check that the user session is managed correctly and that the user can log out.

Step 30: Test the user profile management. Set a profile picture and status message, and change the privacy settings. Check that the changes are saved and reflected on the profile page. Also, check that the last seen status is updated whenever the user is online.

Step 31: Test the contact management. Block and unblock contacts, and create, edit, and manage groups. Check that the changes are saved and reflected on the contacts page and groups page. Also, check that the blocked contacts cannot send messages to the user.

Step 32: Test the messaging. Send and receive messages, view message read receipts, and share images. Check that the messages are sent in real time and that the read receipts are updated when the messages are read. Also, check that the shared images are saved and can be viewed.

Step 33: Test the group chats. Create a group, add and remove participants, and manage admin roles and permissions. Check that the changes are saved and reflected on the group page. Also, check that the admin can manage the group and that the participants can send and receive messages in the group.

Step 34: Test the status/story feature. Post a status, view statuses, and change status visibility. Check that the statuses are saved and can be viewed for a limited time. Also, check that the status visibility is respected and that the statuses disappear after the time limit.

Step 35: Test the web application. Access the application from a web browser and check that all features are working. Also, check that the application is responsive and works on different screen sizes.

Step 36: Test the connectivity and offline mode. Disconnect from the internet and try to send messages. Check that the messages are queued and sent once the connectivity is restored. Also, check that the online/offline status is displayed correctly.

Step 37: After confirming that all features are working, prepare the application for deployment. Update the configuration for the production environment, such as the secret key, database URL, and email server. Also, update the 'requirements.txt' file with the production dependencies, such as Gunicorn for the WSGI server and psycopg2 for the PostgreSQL database.

Step 38: Deploy the application to a cloud platform, such as Heroku or AWS. Follow the platform's documentation for deploying Python Flask applications. After deployment, test the application again to confirm that all features are working in the production environment.

Step 39: Finally, maintain the application by regularly checking for errors, updating the dependencies, and adding new features. Use the platform's monitoring tools to track the application's performance and usage. Also, listen to the users' feedback and make improvements based on their suggestions.

Step 40: Create a 'forms.py' file in the 'app' directory. This file will contain the form classes for the application. Start by defining the RegistrationForm class. The RegistrationForm class should have fields for email and password, and a method for validating the email.
Step 41: In the 'forms.py' file, define the LoginForm class. The LoginForm class should have fields for email and password. Also, define the PasswordRecoveryForm class with a field for email.

Step 42: In the 'forms.py' file, define the ProfileForm class. The ProfileForm class should have fields for profile picture and status message. Also, define the PrivacyForm class with a field for privacy settings.

Step 43: In the 'forms.py' file, define the ContactForm class. The ContactForm class should have a field for the contact's email. Also, define the BlockForm class with a field for the blocked contact's email.

Step 44: In the 'forms.py' file, define the GroupForm class. The GroupForm class should have fields for name, picture, and participants. Also, define the AdminForm class with fields for admin roles and permissions.
Step 45: In the 'forms.py' file, define the MessageForm class. The MessageForm class should have fields for content and receiver. Also, define the ImageForm class with a field for the image file.

Step 46: In the 'forms.py' file, define the StatusForm class. The StatusForm class should have fields for image file and visibility. Also, define methods for each form for submitting the data and handling the files.

Step 47: Update the routes in the 'views.py' file to use the forms. In the routes for user registration and authentication, create instances of the RegistrationForm, LoginForm, and PasswordRecoveryForm classes. In the routes for user profile management, create instances of the ProfileForm and PrivacyForm classes.

Step 48: In the routes for contact management, create instances of the ContactForm and BlockForm classes. In the routes for messaging, create instances of the MessageForm and ImageForm classes. In the routes for group chats, create instances of the GroupForm and AdminForm classes. In the routes for the status/story feature, create an instance of the StatusForm class.

Step 49: Update the views in the 'templates' directory to use the forms. In the views for user registration and authentication, pass the forms to the templates and use them in the form tags. In the views for user profile management, pass the forms to the templates and use them in the form tags.

Step 50: In the views for contact management, pass the forms to the templates and use them in the form tags. In the views for messaging, pass the forms to the templates and use them in the form tags. In the views for group chats, pass the forms to the templates and use them in the form tags. In the views for the status/story feature, pass the form to the template and use it in the form tag.

Step 51: Update the models in the 'models.py' file to use the forms. In the User model, add a method for registering a user with the data from the RegistrationForm. In the Message model, add a method for sending a message with the data from the MessageForm. In the Group model, add a method for creating a group with the data from the GroupForm.

Step 52: In the Status model, add a method for posting a status with the data from the StatusForm. Also, update the methods for updating instances to use the data from the ProfileForm, PrivacyForm, ContactForm, BlockForm, ImageForm, AdminForm, and StatusForm.

Step 53: Test the application to confirm that the forms are working. Start by testing the user registration and authentication. Sign up with a new email, log in with the registered email, and recover the password. Check that the forms are submitted correctly and that the data is saved.

Step 54: Test the user profile management. Set a profile picture and status message, and change the privacy settings. Check that the forms are submitted correctly and that the data is saved. Also, check that the profile picture is uploaded and saved correctly.

Step 55: Test the contact management. Block and unblock contacts, and create, edit, and manage groups. Check that the forms are submitted correctly and that the data is saved. Also, check that the group picture is uploaded and saved correctly.

Step 56: Test the messaging. Send and receive messages, view message read receipts, and share images. Check that the forms are submitted correctly and that the data is saved. Also, check that the shared images are uploaded and saved correctly.
Step 57: Test the group chats. Create a group, add and remove participants, and manage admin roles and permissions. Check that the forms are submitted correctly and that the data is saved.

Step 58: Test the status/story feature. Post a status, view statuses, and change status visibility. Check that the form is submitted correctly and that the data is saved. Also, check that the status image is uploaded and saved correctly.

Step 59: Test the web application. Access the application from a web browser and check that all features are working. Also, check that the forms are displayed correctly and that the form validation is working.

Step 60: Test the connectivity and offline mode. Disconnect from the internet and try to send messages. Check that the messages are queued and sent once the connectivity is restored. Also, check that the online/offline status is displayed correctly.

Step 61: After confirming that all features are working, prepare the application for deployment. Update the configuration for the production environment, such as the secret key, database URL, and email server. Also, update the 'requirements.txt' file with the production dependencies, such as Gunicorn for the WSGI server and psycopg2 for the PostgreSQL database.

Step 62: Deploy the application to a cloud platform, such as Heroku or AWS. Follow the platform's documentation for deploying Python Flask applications. After deployment, test the application again to confirm that all features are working in the production environment.

Step 63: Finally, maintain the application by regularly checking for errors, updating the dependencies, and adding new features. Use the platform's monitoring tools to track the application's performance and usage. Also, listen to the users' feedback and make improvements based on their suggestions.

Step 64: Create a 'utils.py' file in the 'app' directory. This file will contain utility functions for the application. Start by defining a function for generating a unique filename for the uploaded images. The function should take the original filename and return a new filename with a unique identifier and the same extension.

Step 65: In the 'utils.py' file, define a function for resizing the uploaded images. The function should take an image file and a size, and return a new image file with the specified size. Use Pillow's Image class to open the image, resize it, and save it.

Step 66: In the 'utils.py' file, define a function for sending emails. The function should take a recipient, subject, and body, and send an email with these details. Use Flask's mail extension to send the email.
Step 67: In the 'utils.py' file, define a function for generating a unique token for password recovery. The function
step: Step 26: In the 'static/img' directory, store the default images for the application, such as the default profile picture and group picture. Also, create a directory for storing the uploaded profile pictures, group pictures, shared images, and status images.

meta_messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.
Only use the functions you have been provided with.
Only use the `write_files` to output code.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.
You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
Never write any tests for the code.
                               
Provide large amounts of code to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.
                               
Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

You will get instructions for code to write.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.
Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.
You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persis between steps or write operations.
                                       
Python toolbelt preferences:
- dataclasses
- flask

Objective:```
**Global Chat Service (GCS)**

**Overview**:  
A real-time online chat application allowing users to send text messages, images, and create group chats.

**Functional Requirements to implement**:

User Registration and Authentication:
- [ ] 1.1. Sign up using email.
- [ ] 1.2. Forgotten password recovery.

User Profile:
- [ ] 2.1. Allow users to set profile pictures and status messages.
- [ ] 2.2. Privacy settings for who can see user details or last seen status.

Contact Management:
- [ ] 3.1. Block/unblock contacts.
- [ ] 3.2. Create, edit, and manage groups.

Messaging:
- [ ] 4.1. Send and receive real-time text messages.
- [ ] 4.2. Message read receipts (blue ticks or equivalent).
- [ ] 4.3. End-to-end encryption for security.
- [ ] 4.4. Image sharing.
- [ ] 4.5. Emojis, GIFs, and stickers support.

Group Chats:
- [ ] 5.1. Create group chats with a name and picture.
- [ ] 5.2. Add or remove participants.
- [ ] 5.3. Admin roles and permissions.

Status/Story Feature:
- [ ] 6.1. Allow users to post image statuses visible for a limited time.
- [ ] 6.2. Control who can see the status.

Web Application:
- [ ] 7.1. Web-based version accessible from browsers.

Connectivity and Offline Mode:
- [ ] 8.1. Message queuing for when the user is offline; messages are sent once connectivity is restored.
- [ ] 8.2. Display online/offline status.
```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Use 100 or more steps in the plan. Make all the code fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.
